p: The reason branched alkanes are harder to degrade may be either that the alkyl branches hinder the uptake of the hydrocarbons into the cell or that the branches are not susceptible to the enzymes of the β‐oxidation pathway (Schaeffer et al., 1979). One of the conditions necessary for aerobic degradation of branched hydrocarbons in nature is that the bacteria must possess genes and enzymes for initial oxygenation (Britton, 1984; Beguin et al., 2003). The degradation pathways of pristane have been established based on the analyses of the metabolic intermediates formed from pristane using Brevibacterium erythrogenes (Pirnik et al., 1974), Nocardia globerula (Alvarez et al., 2001), and several strains such as Corynebacterium, Mycobacterium and Nocardia (McKenna and Kallio, 1971; Pirnik et al., 1974; Beguin et al., 2003). Pristane is degraded by at least three catabolic pathways: monoterminal, diterminal and subterminal oxidation (Nhi‐Cong et al., 2009). The metabolites produced from monoterminal oxidation of pristane are pristanol, pristyl aldehyde and pristanic acid (Nakajima et al., 1985).
